Resources.Name: Aerated concrete, autoclaved block, non-reinforced, for exterior walls
Resources.StdDescription: Specification for masonry units. Autoclaved aerated concrete masonry units
Resources.GeneralComment: The main raw materials of aerated concrete are cement, lime, finely ground quartz sand, and water. The carbon footprint of the product depends on the shares of raw materials and the energy consumption in autoclave process. EPDs are available for autoclaved aerated concrete products manufactured in Estonia. The emission values published as EPDs for the Estonian aerated concrete blocks and elements are assessed to be representative data for the aerated concrete products used by the construction sector in Finland.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Autoclaved aerated concrete blocks and reinforced elements are not manufactured in Finland. Products are marketed for instance by Bauroc AS. Imports for instance from Estonia.

Resources.Name: Gravel and sand
Resources.StdDescription: Aggregates for concrete.
Resources.GeneralComment: Extraction of the material, washing and sorting with sieves. The main factor behind the carbon footprint of natural sand and gravel is the energy used in these processes. Average from Ökobaudat and Eco Platform values is proposed, the data is valid (until 2022 and 2023, resp.) and all processes are included.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Aggregates used in Finland are all produced in Finland. Some export to Estonia. Some of the manufacturers are Rudus, Swerock (ex. YIT), Destia, NCC and Seepsula.

Conversions.Value: Density 1500 kg/m3

Resources.Name: Air exchanger with heat recovery
Resources.StdDescription: Ventilation for buildings
Resources.GeneralComment: Air exchanger with heat recovery is manufactured by assembling components of the appliance. When only considering the product stage of the system, the biggest embodied carbon contribution comes from the metal parts, predominantly steel and aluminum parts of the system. If also considering the use stage of the product, due to the energy usage (and energy saved) in the use phase, that would become the biggest contributor to the product’s carbon emissions throughout the whole life cycle of the product.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: The domestic manufacturing market share is unknown. Imports are predominantly coming from Europe.

Resources.Name: Aluminium foil, scrap 0%
Resources.StdDescription: Aluminium and aluminium alloys. Structural products for construction works. Technical conditions for inspection and delivery.
Resources.GeneralComment: The most essential issue that affects the climate impact of aluminium products is the scrap content. According to EEA, secondary aluminium based production requires roughly 5 % of the original energy consumption. All aluminium products can be recycled after use. Aluminium losses in melting are low, roughly 3 %. The current recycling rate in construction sector for aluminium is estimated at 96 %.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: At present, China produces the majority (54%) of primary aluminium in the world. Other regions hold a much smaller share. Europe represents 7% of global production. There is aluminium metal supply industry (primary and recycling) in Norway, Iceland, and Sweden. In addition, there are several aluminium plants in all Nordic countries involved in extrusion. In Finland, all aluminium metal - including primary and recycled – is imported. The biggest manufacturers of aluminium profiles in Finland are Purso Oy and Mäkelä Alu.

Resources.Name: Bathroom full height cabinet
Resources.GeneralComment: Cabinets and closet frames are made from wood-based boards, with predominant board types varying between MDF and melamine-coated particleboard. Essential driving factor is the total mass of the cabinets, which is a function of the board type and thickness and spacing of the cabinets (smaller cabinets need more separating walls). Any cabinets or closets made using material from unsustainable forestry would have a clearly higher carbon footprint. The cabinets and the board used therein are manufactured in a number of different locations, which causes variations in their manufacturing and transport embodied carbon.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume:
The Finnish market for bathroom closets is led by domestic manufacturers, Polaria and Temal. Predominant import sources are Nordic and Baltic countries. The market share of bathroom cabinets domestic manufacturing is approximately 60% and the share of import 40%. In full height closet market, the share of import is lower, and the share of domestic manufacturing would be approximately 80%.  
Information herein is based on market research and interviews with Puutuoteteollisuus and Temal Oy.

Conversions.Value: PRODUCT’S DIMENSIONS (WxHxD) 60 cm x 182 cm x 60 cm

Resources.Name: Bathroom faucet
Resources.StdDescription: Sanitary tapware – Single taps and combination taps for water supply systems of type 1 and type 2
Resources.GeneralComment: The carbon intensity of brass contributes significantly to the product’s GWP value. However, by using scrap materials in brass production, it is possible to achieve lower carbon footprint values compared to the proposed value. The GWP is mainly dominated by the use of electricity in the manufacturing process. As the usage of recycled materials differs in the market, the GWP values can be greatly increased when no scrap materials are used.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: The Finnish market for faucets and showers is dominated by Oras, whose market share (of mainly domestically manufactured products) is estimated to be approximately 70%. Competitors import products manufactured in Europe, and they include Hangsrohe, Mora, FM Mattson and others.

Conversions.Value: PRODUCT’s DIMENSIONS 33 mm x 146 mm x 144 mm

Resources.Name: Bitumen waterproofing membrane, bottom layer TL2/TL3
Resources.StdDescription: Flexible sheets for waterproofing. Reinforced bitumen sheets for waterproofing. Definitions and characteristics.
Resources.GeneralComment: Bitumen roll roofing or membrane is a waterproofing product which consists of bitumen, a support layer, fillers and is covered with mineral granules. In Finland, as well as in the other Nordic countries, the manufacturing of bitumen waterproofing almost exclusively uses bitumen modified with SBS (styrene-butadiene-styrene). The average values are based on the market’s largest manufacturers products for bitumen roofing. The values are calculated on the basis of data gathered from manufacturers and represent the common products. These manufacturers represent over 95 % of the Finnish bitumen roofing market.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: In Finland BMI Icopal, Nordic Waterproofing Suomi (product name Kerabit), and Katepal Oy manufacture bitumen sheets for water proofing. The market is largely domestic. Roughly estimated share of imports is <20% in the market.

Conversions.Value: Thickness about 3 mm, nominal weight 4 kg / m2.

Resources.Name: Asphalt concrete
Resources.StdDescription: Asphalt concrete
Resources.GeneralComment: The differences in the carbon footprint come mainly from the amount of recycled material and the heating process. In case of proposed values, only virgin sources are used for manufacturing. Therefore, it is assumed that 100 % of the product will be disposed at the end-of-life phase. Carbon footprint of heating is affected by the temperature and the fuel used in heating process. In this proposal the carbon footprint has been calculated on the basis of the amount of material used in the asphalt (excluding the use of recycled asphalt). The product compositions used are based in part on PANK study material C10.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: In 2019 the production was 5.34 milj. tonnes, which was divided by the customers: Centres for Economic Development, Transport and the Environment 34 %, aviation 1 %, municipalities 22 %, private 43 %.

Conversions.Value: Density 2496 kg/m3.

Resources.Name: Brick, light
Resources.StdDescription: Specification for masonry units. Part 1: Clay masonry units
Resources.GeneralComment: Clay bricks are manufactured of clay, sand, lime and sawdust. The bricks are burned in a tunnel furnace at a high temperature. The average GWP value is based on the information provided by the Brick Industry Group Finland. These results are close to the values published by (RTS EPD) Wienerberger which is the market leader in Finland.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Three manufacturers produce clay bricks in Finland: Wienerberger, Tiileri and Räikkönen. Wienerberger is the biggest manufacturer. Domestic production covers roughly 90% of the market. Small amounts of bricks are imported for instance from Denmark, the Netherlands, Belgium and Germany.

Conversions.Value: Manufacturers give information about consumption of bricks per square meter . GWP (kg)/m2 can be calculated by multiplying the given carbon footprint with the number of bricks per 1 m2 and the weight of a brick (kg) per piece. In addition mortar is needed in accordance with the instructions of manufacturers.

Resources.Name: Accommodation / hotel
Resources.GeneralComment:
The proposed emission value for building services equipment is based on data modeling of building designs from the lists of equipment and electrical components of the contractors. All sites were real construction projects. The values are given separately for the following building types: small residential building, apartment building, office, educational building/kindergarten, accommodation building/hotel, hospital, sports hall, other retail building. The unit is kg CO2e / m2. These values include whole evaluation period including maintenance and product replacements. With regard to the calculation of emissions from building technology materials, a conservative factor of 1.2 has been taken into account.

The emissions of the cooling system for educational buildings/kindergartens and small residential buildings must be added separately if the cooling system is planned. Sprinkler system for fire extinguishing is not included.

Resources.Name: Educational building, kindergarten
Resources.GeneralComment:
The proposed emission value for building services equipment is based on data collected from actual Finnish projects. All sites were real construction projects. The values are given separately for the following building types: office, shopping center, shop, educational building, accommodation building, residential apartment building. The unit is kg CO2e / m2. These values include whole evaluation period including maintenance and product replacements.

With regard to the calculation of emissions from building technology materials, a conservative factor of 1.2 has been taken into account before the use phase. No conservative factor has been used for in-service replaceable parts, as a large proportion of replaceable parts are metal and thus it is assumed that there will be a significant reduction in emissions from metal fabrication before the need to replace components in building services systems.

For educational buildings and apartment buildings cooling system emissions need to added should there be a cooling system designed. Fire extinguishing system should be added for apartment buildings, when needed.
Resources.TechnologyDescriptionAndIncludedProcesse: Based on the research data used, the materials of the ventilation system make up the vast majority of the emissions of all building types. After this, the most significant of the office projects are the cooling system with space equipment and in other locations the heating system with space equipment. Emissions in residential buildings are clearly lower than in other building types due to lighter lighting and the lack of cooling and sprinkler systems.

Resources.Name: Calcium silicate brick
Resources.StdDescription: Specification for masonry units. Part 2: Calcium silicate masonry units
Resources.GeneralComment:
Calcium silicate bricks and blocks are made from a mixture of burnt lime, quartz-rich sand, and water. The mixture is pressed with high pressure. The selected average value is based on the published EPD by the only Finnish manufacture.
Application in load-bearing and non-load-bearing structures.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Kiikala factory (Weber) is the only calcium silicate brick manufacturing plant in the Nordic countries. The whole production volume is used in Finland. Calcium silicate bricks for facades are not currently manufactured but blocks for facades (protected masonry).

Conversions.Value: Solutions for alternative load-bearing and non-load-bearing purposes together with information of need of bricks or blocks per m2 of different kinds of walls are given by the Finnish manufacture.

Resources.Name: Cellulose insulation board
Resources.GeneralComment: Cellulose insulation is made from sorted recycled paper and from magnesium sulfate, boric acid etc. used as flame retardants. The share of recycled newsprint in the content of blowing cellulose insulation products is roughly 90%. The values are based on the results published by Ekovilla for loose-fill cellulose insulation and for boards.The value for boards is quite close to the value reported in ÖkobauDat.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: In Finland, there are three manufacturers of cellulose insulation materials. Ekovilla manufactures both loose-fill insulation products and boards. Resources.Name: Cellulose insulation, loose-fill
Resources.GeneralComment: Cellulose insulation is made from sorted recycled paper and from magnesium sulfate, boric acid etc. used as flame retardants. The share of recycled newsprint in the content of blowing cellulose insulation products is roughly 90%. The values are based on the results published by Ekovilla for loose-fill cellulose insulation and for boards. Ekovilla is the biggest manufacture for loose-fill cellulose insulation in Finland and the process is very similar in Ekovilla and Termex which is the second biggest manufacturer. Currently Termex has not an EPD representative for Finland but the average result for ECIA (European Cellulose Insulation Association) covers also Termex.

Ekovilla is the biggest manufacture and has a major share in the domestic market. Cellulose fibre insulations based on recycled paper are also manufactured in Sweden. Resources.Name: Chipboard
Resources.StdDescription: Floor and ceiling panels for buildings.
Resources.GeneralComment: Chipboards are made of wood chips and adhesive by pressing. In Finland secondary material flows from the manufacturing of sawn timber are utilized in chipboards. Urea-formaldehyde resin is usually used as the adhesive, which typically accounts for less than 10% of the mass of chipboards. Densities vary between 650 and 750 kg/m3. Based on the studied EPDs, the GWP values for chipboards vary between 0.3 and 0.45, therefore Koskisen values are well in line with these values and proposed to be used as the average values.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Koskisen Oy is the only manufacturer of chip board in Finland. Its production covers roughly 50 % of the whole market. Koskisen Oy manufactures both melamine coated and uncoated boards. Chipboard is imported from Estonia and from Germany and other middle European countries. Big manufacturers are for instance Kronospan and Egger.

Conversions.Value: Density 700 kg/m3, moisture content ≈7%

Resources.Name: CLT, Cross laminated timber
Resources.StdDescription: CLT-boads have no harmonised European standard. CLT can be CE marked on the basis of European technical certification.
Resources.GeneralComment: CLT (Cross Laminated Timber) consists of cross laminated timber boards. The number of boards is usually three or five. The raw material of boards is usually spruce or pine. Boards are glued and pressed. There is lack of relevant data for CLT. At present, there is no EPDs available for domestic CLT. The proposal is to apply an estimate based on the Finnish value for sawn timber supplemented by information provided by Stora Enso for CLT manufacturing.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Cross laminated timber is manufactured in Finland by three manufacturers: Hoisko, CLT Plant, Croslam. StoraEnso imports CTL from Austria. In addition, CLT is imported from Latvia and Estonia. Domestic manufacturing covers roughly 60 – 70 % of the market. However, the share of domestic manufacturing varies in accordance with the use purpose. Domestic CLT is used especially in small houses while in big building projects, the use of imported CLT is also typical.

Resources.Name: Copper sheet
Resources.StdDescription: Copper and copper alloys - Sheet and strip for building purposes
Resources.GeneralComment: The greatest influence comes from the raw materials used (ores, concentrates and scrap). Because of the significant market share of the Nordic manufacturers, it is proposed that the carbon footprint values reported by Aurubis and Elektrokoppar will be used as generic values for sheets and wires. The result reported by Aurubis for sheets manufactured with using Cu-alloy and 97% scrap is significantly lower compared to the European average values (75% smaller than European average, where scrap content varies) and also compared to the results published by KME (roughly 50% smaller, both have roughly 100 % scrap content).

Resources.Name: Energy, district cooling
Resources.GeneralComment: The emission factors for electricity, district heat, and district cooling, and for fossil and bio fuels for heating of buildings were assessed based on statistical data and earlier research results.
Resources.TechnologyDescriptionAndIncludedProcesse:
The specific emissions were based on GHGs from yearly domestic production and considering the net import of electricity. The specific GHGs from electricity and district heat production were estimated considering CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from the combustion and procurement of fuels (except CO2 from combustion of biomass-based fuels), and the construction of the capacity infrastructure for fuel supply and heat and power generation. The CO2 emissions from the combustion of biomass were calculated as zero emissions. The influence of harvesting of biomass on carbon sinks of forests or soil was not considered.
The emission values were also assessed for energy services for coming decades considering the targeted decarbonization of energy services. The applied assumptions are based on the basic scenario for 2020 – 2050 presented by VTT and SYKE in PITKO project (Long-term emission trends) documentation.
GHGs of fossil fuels for building heating in decentralized systems were assessed for light heating oil considering the emissions caused by procurement and construction of infra in addition to combustion. The specific emissions for biofuels were formulated by using the same factors as was used for chips for in the connection of emission-assessment of electricity and district heat. The assessed emissions because of transportation and manufacturing were added following the principles of EU REDII Directive (EU 2018). The specific emission factors for fossil fuels and biofuels for decentralized heating of buildings were assumed to remain unchanged throughout the period considered.

Resources.GeneralComment: The emission factors for electricity, district heat, and district cooling, and for fossil and bio fuels for heating of buildings were assessed based on statistical data and earlier research results.
Resources.TechnologyDescriptionAndIncludedProcesse:
The specific emissions were based on GHGs from yearly domestic production and considering the net import of electricity. The specific GHGs from electricity and district heat production were estimated considering CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from the combustion and procurement of fuels (except CO2 from combustion of biomass-based fuels), and the construction of the capacity infrastructure for fuel supply and heat and power generation. The CO2 emissions from the combustion of biomass were calculated as zero emissions. The influence of harvesting of biomass on carbon sinks of forests or soil was not considered.
The emission values were also assessed for energy services for coming decades considering the targeted decarbonization of energy services. The applied assumptions are based on the basic scenario for 2020 – 2050 presented by VTT and SYKE in PITKO project (Long-term emission trends) documentation.
GHGs of fossil fuels for building heating in decentralized systems were assessed for light heating oil considering the emissions caused by procurement and construction of infra in addition to combustion. The specific emissions for biofuels were formulated by using the same factors as was used for chips for in the connection of emission-assessment of electricity and district heat. The assessed emissions because of transportation and manufacturing were added following the principles of EU REDII Directive (EU 2018). The specific emission factors for fossil fuels and biofuels for decentralized heating of buildings were assumed to remain unchanged throughout the period considered.

Resources.Name: Door, indoor flush door
Resources.GeneralComment: There are two kinds of generally used flush doors that vary on their components: the massive flush door and the light flush door. Flush doors for homes are typically made with HDF frame and have an internal honeycomb core. However, they can be also made of MDF, making them heavier compared to the HDF ones. The wood-based materials, such as chipboard, solid wood and particleboards have a similar contribution to the end result. Any doors made using material from unsustainable forestry would have a clearly higher carbon footprint.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Many companies manufacture both windows and doors, and these include Inwido Group companies (Pihla and Eskopuu), Skaala and Kaskipuu. Companies specializing in door manufacturing include for example Jeld-Wen, which is a major flush door manufacturer. The share of domestic manufacturing for flush doors is approximately 70%.

Conversions.Value: PRODUCT’S DIMENSIONS (WxHxD) 100 cm x 210 cm x 4 cm

Resources.Name: Door, metallic, fire-rated
Resources.StdDescription: Pedestrian doorsets, industrial, commercial, garage doors and openable windows. Product standard, performance characteristics. Fire resisting and/or smoke control characteristics
Resources.GeneralComment: Fire compartmentalization doors are metal framed doors with different levels of insulation inside, most common fire retarding times are 30 and 60 minutes. The key factors impacting embodied carbon in metal door products is steel (galvanized) and mineral wool. The raw material acquisition’s effect on the embodied carbon comes mainly from the use of steel products and their upstream chains as well as through the use of automatic drives and their respective upstream chains. However, the manufacturing stage has only a moderate contribution in terms of the total amount of emissions due to the use of electricity and heat consumption in the assembly.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Companies specializing in door manufacturing include for example Jeld-Wen and HRT-Steel. In terms of fire and safety doors, the leading domestic manufacturer is Forssan Metallityöt. Domestic manufacturing market share is estimated to represent over three quarters of the total market. Imports are predominantly coming from near abroad.

Resources.Name: Door, outdoor, wooden with steel frame
Resources.StdDescription: Windows and external doorsets
Resources.GeneralComment: The most of the embodied carbon in wooden doors comes from the main materials and the insulation used in making doors. Wooden doors are made from wood-based products, with insulation and possible glazing. However, in steel framed wooden doors, the steel frame is generally the biggest contributors in terms of the embodied carbon footprint. The manufacturing stage is also a significant contributor also due to the energy use in the production stages. Any doors made using material from unsustainable forestry would have a clearly higher carbon footprint than figures given here.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland

Wooden doors are made from wood-based products, with insulation and possible glazing. However, in steel framed wooden doors, the steel frame is generally the biggest contributors in terms of the embodied carbon footprint. The manufacturing stage is also a significant contributor also due to the energy use in the production stages. Any doors made using material from unsustainable forestry would have a clearly higher carbon footprint than figures given here.

Resources.Name: Energy, electricity consumption
Resources.GeneralComment: The emission factors for electricity, district heat, and district cooling, and for fossil and bio fuels for heating of buildings were assessed based on statistical data and earlier research results.
Resources.TechnologyDescriptionAndIncludedProcesse:
The specific emissions were based on GHGs from yearly domestic production and considering the net import of electricity. The specific GHGs from electricity and district heat production were estimated considering CO2, CH4, and N2O emissions from the combustion and procurement of fuels (except CO2 from combustion of biomass-based fuels), and the construction of the capacity infrastructure for fuel supply and heat and power generation. The CO2 emissions from the combustion of biomass were calculated as zero emissions. The influence of harvesting of biomass on carbon sinks of forests or soil was not considered.
The emission values were also assessed for energy services for coming decades considering the targeted decarbonization of energy services. The applied assumptions are based on the basic scenario for 2020 – 2050 presented by VTT and SYKE in PITKO project (Long-term emission trends) documentation.
GHGs of fossil fuels for building heating in decentralized systems were assessed for light heating oil considering the emissions caused by procurement and construction of infra in addition to combustion. The specific emissions for biofuels were formulated by using the same factors as was used for chips for in the connection of emission-assessment of electricity and district heat. The assessed emissions because of transportation and manufacturing were added following the principles of EU REDII Directive (EU 2018). The specific emission factors for fossil fuels and biofuels for decentralized heating of buildings were assumed to remain unchanged throughout the period considered.

Resources.GeneralComment: The elevator consists mainly of ferrous metals, such as zinc-coated steel, stainless, steel, cold rolled steel, etc. that contribute significantly to the embodied carbon of the product. However, the majority of ferrous metal products can be recycled after the end of life of the elevator. Elevators contain a significant variety of materials. The information herein is based on market research and discussion with a KONE representative.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Passenger elevators used in Finland are mainly produced by KONE. Other manufactures include Schindler and Otis.  Share of domestic manufacturing is not known.

Expanded Polystyrene (EPS) is a lightweight foam insulation material produced by expanding polystyrene using steam. The A1 phase dominates regarding the GWP of EPS. Resources.Name: Expanded clay crushed aggregate
Resources.StdDescription: Thermal insulation products for buildings. In-situ formed expanded clay lightweight aggregate products. Part 1: Specification for the loose-fill products before installation
Resources.GeneralComment: Expanded clay is a ceramic granular material made of natural clay. The share of clay is >95%. Clay and additives mixed with it are incinerated in a rotary oven at a temperature of about 1150 Celsius degrees. In the combustion, the clay swells and forms sintered 0-32 mm granules by the rotating movement of the furnace . Fuel consumption during the combustion process is the main factor Influencing the carbon footprint of expanded clay. The proposed value for expanded clay crushed aggregate is based on the EPD published by Weber in 2020. The representativeness is good regarding the Finnish construction sector.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: In Finland expanded clay products are manufactured by Leca Finland Oy. The product is marketed with the brand name Leca. Leca is also manufactured in other European countries including Denmark and Norway. There are no imports but minor amounts within the company (Leca Finland).

The GWP values reported in published EPDs of fibre cement boards vary. Cement content is one of the main issues that explains the variation. The selected value is calculated as an average of the collected values.

Resources.Name: Foamed glass crushed aggregate
Resources.GeneralComment: The values are based on the results published by Uusioaines Oy (RTS EPD), which is the only manufacturer in Finland. The crushed aggregate manufactured of recycled glass is used as light-weight and insulating material in infra structures and in building construction. Foamed glass is made of cleaned recycled glass, which is crushed to 0.1 mm grain size. After crushing, a separate flotation agent is added. The glass is heated and melted roughly at 900 Celsius degree. The added flotation agent makes the glass to swell. When cooled, the pulp hardens and crushes forming porous grains (pore content roughly 92 %). The material is crushed and sieved to achieve the desired grain size. Carbon footprint is especially determined by the type of fuels used for heating.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Foamed glass crushed aggregate is manufactured in Finland only in Forssa near the glass cleaning plant Uusioaines Oy under product name Foamit. The plant has a production capacity of 250,000 m3 /v. In other Nordic countries, such as Norway and Sweden, the material has been used for a longer time than in Finland.

Resources.Name: Acoustic panel, glass wool 20 mm, sound absorption class A
Resources.StdDescription: Thermal insulation products for buildings. Factory made mineral wool (MW) products.
Resources.GeneralComment: Glass wool is manufactured from mineral raw materials and recycled glass through melting, fiberizing, injection of binders, curing in an oven and cutting. The main issue that affects the carbon footprint of the product is the consumption and source of energy in the melting phase, and in other phases of the process. The share of recycled glass is > 50 % of mineral raw materials of glass wool manufactured in Finland. Considering the environmental impact of cullet usage, for every 10% of cullet used in glass manufacturing, energy consumption is reduced by roughly 2.5% and CO2 emissions by 5%. On the basis of GWP values (A1 – A3) of glass wool collected from various sources, the differences are rather big. The values vary roughly from 1 – 2 kg CO2e/kg product. The average for glass wool products manufactured in Finland is roughly 1 kg/kg. The proposal is to apply the average value calculated on the basis of the recent results published in the EPDs of the Finnish manufacturer. These products have a high share of the market of glass wool used in buildings in Finland. Thus, the representativeness regarding the Finnish construction sector is good.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: The market of mineral wool in Finland is largely domestic. Regarding the Finnish manufacturers, the two biggest manufacturers are Saint Gobain with Isover glass wool and Paroc with stone wool. A big share of glass wool used in the Finnish construction sector is manufactured by Saint Gobain. Mineral wool is also imported from Russia, Poland, and other countries.

Conversions.Value: Weight 2,1 kg/m2

Resources.Name: Glass wool insulation, density 60 kg/m3
Resources.StdDescription: Thermal insulation products for buildings. Factory made mineral wool (MW) products.
Resources.GeneralComment: Glass wool is manufactured from mineral raw materials and recycled glass through melting, fiberizing, injection of binders, curing in an oven and cutting. The main issue that affects the carbon footprint of the product is the consumption and source of energy in the melting phase, and in other phases of the process. The share of recycled glass is > 50 % of mineral raw materials of glass wool manufactured in Finland. Considering the environmental impact of cullet usage, for every 10% of cullet used in glass manufacturing, energy consumption is reduced by roughly 2.5% and CO2 emissions by 5%. On the basis of GWP values (A1 – A3) of glass wool collected from various sources, the differences are rather big. The values vary roughly from 1 – 2 kg CO2e/kg product. The average for glass wool products manufactured in Finland is roughly 1 kg/kg. The proposal is to apply the average value calculated on the basis of the recent results published in the EPDs of the Finnish manufacturer. These products have a high share of the market of glass wool used in buildings in Finland. Thus, the representativeness regarding the Finnish construction sector is good.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: The market of mineral wool in Finland is largely domestic. Regarding the Finnish manufacturers, the two biggest manufacturers are Saint Gobain with Isover glass wool and Paroc with stone wool. A big share of glass wool used in the Finnish construction sector is manufactured by Saint Gobain. Mineral wool is also imported from Russia, Poland, and other countries.

Conversions.Value: Quantity required for thermal resistance of 1 m2 K/W = 2.516 kg/m2

Resources.Name: Glass-aluminium facade, triple-glazed
Resources.StdDescription: Windows and external doorsets
Resources.GeneralComment: The raw materials acquisition (A1) can be identified as a hotspot for the embodied carbon values. The high amount of glass and aluminium contributes mostly to a higher carbon footprint. In glass-aluminium facades the production of the aluminium frame and the mass proportion of the glass have a significant impact in the carbon emissions of the product. Also, the energy consumption in the assembly and final manufacturing contributes to the carbon footprint. The origin of the forestry is a very significant driver for the product embodied carbon.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: The Finnish market for windows is led by domestic manufacturers, including Inwido Group companies (Pihla, Tiivi and Eskopuu) and Skaala, Kaskipuu, Fenestra, Tikli and Lammin Ikkunat. The market share of domestic manufacturing is estimated to be approximately 90%. All window glass used in Finland is imported. Share of the aluminium frames is imported as well.

Conversions.Value: PRODUCT’S DIMENSION (WxHxD) 1m2

Resources.Name: GLT, Glued laminated timber
Resources.StdDescription: Timber structures. Glued laminated timber and glued solid timber. Requirements.
Resources.GeneralComment: The raw material is Nordic coniferous wood (mainly spruce but also pine and larch) and relatively small amount of adhesive. Finished glued wood products are delivered dried to a moisture content of 12%. At present, there are no valid EPDs available for glued laminated wood columns or beams manufactured in Finland. The proposed GWP value is calculated on the basis of the GWP value for planed timber (in accordance with this database) and the estimated GWP of MUF adhesive. The value was compared with the published results by manufacturers in Sweden and Norway.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: In Finland, 13 manufacturers produce glued laminated timber. The three biggest manufacturers are Keitele Group, FLT ja VersoWood which are responsible for roughly 60 – 70 % of the Finnish gluelam market. The importing of glued laminated timber in Finland is minor – a rough assessment is below 1000 m3 per year.

Conversions.Value: Density 430 kg/m3, moisture content 15%

Resources.Name: GLVL, multiple glued laminated veneer lumber
Resources.StdDescription: Timber structures. Structural laminated veneer lumber. Requirements
Resources.GeneralComment: LVL is a beam or wood panel product made by gluing coniferous veneers. The used resin is phenol formaldehyde resin. Several panels of such “primary” LVL can be bonded by face-gluing in order to achieve an LVL product with larger thicknesses, called glued laminated LVL (GLVL). In Finland, LVL is produced by gluing 3 mm thick coniferous veneers. The indicator values were defined separately for two different densities 510 kg/m3 and 440 kg/m3. Average value based on the EPDs reported by MetsäWood and StoraEnso is proposed for the generic value of LVL. A separate value is also given for GLVL. This is based on the results published by Stora Enso.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: LVL is produced by MetsäWood and Stora Enso in Finland. Metsä Wood has the biggest manufacturing capacity for LVL in Europe. Two other big manufacturers are Steico and Stora Enso: Metsä Wood, 2 mills, capacity 300 000 m3/year (Finland), Steico 1 mill, Capacity 160 000 m3/year (Poland) , Stora Enso, 1 mill, Capacity 100 000 m3/year. (Finland). LVL is imported from Russia (11 000 m3) and small amounts from Germany and Poland. The share of domestic production is assumed to be high.

Conversions.Value: GWP fossil (A1-A3)=175 kg/m3. Density 510 kg/m3, moisture content at delivery 10%

Resources.Name: Gypsum plasterboard for interior use
Resources.StdDescription: Gypsum plasterboards. Definitions, requirements and test methods
Resources.GeneralComment: Gypsum plasterboard is used indoors. It consists of two sheets of cardboard and a gypsum layer in between them. The raw materials for gypsum plasterboards are calcinated gypsum, cardboard and additives. The gypsum is either from mined gypsum, by-product gypsum, or recycled gypsum. As the market share of domestic manufacture of gypsum boards is high, and as the carbon footprint emissions values of the boards manufactured in Finland are rather on the same level, the emission and density values were calculated as average values on the basis of the Finnish EPDs.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Gypsum boards are manufactured in Finland by Gyproc Saint Gobain and Knauf Oy. Gyproc is the market leader responding for roughly two thirds of the market. Domestic manufacturers have a large market share. According to statistics, the imports of gypsum boards are low.

Resources.Name: Heat treated planed timber for indoor use
Resources.GeneralComment: In Finland, heat-treated timber is made of pine, spruce, or hardwood sawn timber by the ThermoWood® process. The process is based on the use of high temperature and water vapour. The environmental impacts can vary significantly in accordance with the type of the process, types of fuels and transportation distances. Energy consumption contributes considerably to the environmental impact of thermally treated wood. In addition, the transportation of timber from several saw mills may have an essential impact. The environmental impacts can vary significantly in accordance with the type of the process, types of fuels and transportation distances. Energy consumption contributes considerably to the environmental impact of thermally treated wood. In addition, the transportation of timber from several saw mills may have an essential impact.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: ThermoWood/Finland is the largest producer of thermally modified timber in the world and biggest of all the commercial wood modification businesses. In 2014, the production of ThermoWood was 150,000 m3. Production is mainly from scots pine and norway spruce, and 80% of the production is sold within Europe. The total annual production of thermally modified timber in Europe is about 300,000 m3. LunaWood is the biggest manufacturer is Finland. The annual capacity is roughly 155 000 m3 . Today, Luna exports over 95% of production.

Conversions.Value: Moisture content 5%, density 390 kg/m3, applicable only for heat treated timber manufactured with the help of a specific process.

Resources.Name: Impregnated timber
Resources.GeneralComment: Pressure impregnated wood is pine wood. The product is industrially manufactured and impregnated in impregnation plants. Wood is treated with impregnation to prevent deforestation and blueing of wood. Preservative substances are impregnated in an impregnation cylinder using water and pressure. In Finland, pressure-impregnated sawn timber is pine sawn timber impregnated with a saturation agent (C-impregnation) containing copper compounds in classes A and AB. EPDs are not available for impregnated timber. The GWP value was calculated as the average calculated for the collected Norwegian results (->0,13 kg/kg and 71 kg/m3) and modified to better represent the Finnish manufacturing. The Norwegian results have been calculated by using the emission value 30 g/kWh for electricity which is significantly lower than in Finland.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Kestopuuteollisuus ry is an industry association of companies operating in the field of wood preservation. Its members are companies that manufacture impregnated wood, as well as companies that manufacture and import impregnation substances. The web page of the association lists 11 manufacturers in Finland. It is assumed here that the share of domestic manufacturing is high in the market.

Conversions.Value: GWP fossil (A1-A3)=71 kg/m3, Carbon storage (in CO2e)=797 kg/m3

Resources.Name: Kitchen wall cabinet
Resources.GeneralComment: Cabinets and closet frames are made from wood-based boards, with predominant board types varying between MDF and melamine-coated particleboard. Essential driving factor is the total mass of the cabinets, which is a function of the board type and thickness and spacing of the cabinets (smaller cabinets need more separating walls). Any cabinets or closets made using material from unsustainable forestry would have a clearly higher carbon footprint. The cabinets and the board used therein are manufactured in a number of different locations, which causes variations in their manufacturing and transport embodied carbon.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: The Finnish market for kitchen cabinets is led by domestic Puustelli and Novart (Petra and A la Carte brands). Major importers include IKEA kitchens, Noblessa (Germany) and Gigantti (Epoq brand). The market share of domestic manufacturing is approximately 70% and the share of import 30%.

Resources.Name: Partition wall, glass with aluminium frame
Resources.GeneralComment: For partition walls the biggest impact comes from the raw materials mainly due to glass. The contribution from glass as a raw material increases as the thickness of the glass increases. In terms of glass-aluminium partition walls, aluminium has higher emissions even though its use is not as significant as the use of glass. In glass-wood partition walls the emissions depend also heavily on the origin of the wood used. Any doors made using material from unsustainable forestry would have a clearly higher carbon footprint.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Partition walls are most often made with aluminium frame, but wood and steel are also used. Domestic manufacturers include HSL Group, HRT-Steel and Lasitehdas, among others. Glass partition walls are also imported, in particular from Baltic countries. The market share of domestic manufacturing is unknown.

Resources.Name: Plywood, birch, coated
Resources.StdDescription: Wood-based panels for use in construction. Characteristics, evaluation of conformity and marking
Resources.GeneralComment: Plywood is made from thin wood veneers by gluing. The thickness of an individual veneer is between 0.2 and 3.2 mm. There is usually an odd number of veneers in birch plywood (at least three). The adhesive is usually weather- and boil-resistant phenol formaldehyde resin. There are several EPDs available for plywood products manufactured in the Nordic countries. However, some of the results are outdated and are being currently recalculated. Proposal for coated birch plywood is the values given in EPDs by Koskisen and MetsäWood.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Metsä Wood and UPM manufacture birch and softwood plywood and Koskisen Oy and Riga Wood Finland Oy manufacture only birch plywood in Finland. Plywood was manufactured total of 1.090 million m3 in Finland in 2019. Majority of the products is exported (ca. 84 % in 2019). The import of plywood in 2019 was 0.118 million m3. Majority of the imported plywood comes from Russia, Brazilian, Latvia and Estonia. The share of domestic production of the plywood sold in Finland was ca. 59% in 2019.

Conversions.Value: Density 680 kg/m3, moisture content 8%

Resources.Name: Earthwork
Resources.GeneralComment:
The proposed emission values for construction site are based on the results collected from recent Finnish and Swedish studies. All considered studies were case studies based on real construction projects. Values are given separately for earthwork and other part of construction, and separately for different kinds of building types:
- construction, residential building (excluding earthwork)
- construction, school building or kindergarten (excluding earthwork)
- construction, office building (excluding earthwork)
- earthwork (in terms of kg CO2e/m2 (gross)
- earthwork (in terms of CO2e/l (estimated consumption of fuel))
- stabilization
Resources.TechnologyDescriptionAndIncludedProcesse:
Values are given separately for earthwork and other part of construction, and separately for different kinds of building types.
Based on researched documents, seasonal variance of energy consumption is significant. Heating and lighting of construction site cause the large increase in energy consumption during winter months.
The share of heating energy consumption may be around 70 % of total energy consumption (excluding earthworks and transportation) of construction.
In summary, the important factors that explain the variation in energy consumption during phase A5 are as follows:
• the outdoor temperatures during winter season as the harshness of winter may vary greatly between years,
• the seasonal time of concreting,
• the degree of prefabrication and use of elements and space elements, and
• the use of overall shelters.

Conversions.Value:
A 5 earth work / working machine related service 
GWP = 3,23 kg CO2e/l (fuel)
Emissions per hour: 
Average of drivable diesel machines 27,2 kg CO2e kg/h
Average of main working machines (excavators, loaders, bulldozers) 32,6 kg CO2e kg/h.

Resources.Name: Demolition, office building
Resources.GeneralComment:
The after-use phase is divided to the following four sub-phases:
• C1 Deconstruction demolition
• C2 Transport
• C3 Waste processing
• C4 Disposal
GWP for demolition is given for C1, C3, and C4, C2 is dealt with on the bases of GWP for transportation service.
GWP value for C1 is given for three different building types.
GWP for waste processing is given separately for a few building materials. The data is mainly based on EPDs.
GWP for C4 is based on the emission value for recovered fuels and on the assumption of the share of combustible waste fraction.
Resources.TechnologyDescriptionAndIncludedProcesse:
The main part of mixed waste assessed by weight - consists of concrete and other mineral materials. Mixed waste from building sites is not applicable for combustion. The different fractions need to be separated on buildings sites , or at latest on waste separation plants .
Statistics Finland has published emission values for different kinds of fuels. The value for recovered fuels is 0,57 kg CO2/kg.
The proposal for phase C4 is
- to provide a generic emission value with regard to the building-scale amount of combustible waste generated at demolition site
- to use a value given for recovered fuels by Statistics Finland (0,57 kg CO2 / kg)
- When the share of combustible waste fraction cannot be assessed a default value or 10% can be used which leads to the emission value of 0,057 kg CO2 / kg of all mixed waste.

The main part of mixed waste assessed by weight - consists of concrete and other mineral materials. Mixed waste from building sites is not applicable for combustion. The different fractions need to be separated on buildings sites , or at latest on waste separation plants .
Statistics Finland has published emission values for different kinds of fuels. The value for recovered fuels is 0,57 kg CO2/kg.
The proposal for phase C4 is
- to provide a generic emission value with regard to the building-scale amount of combustible waste generated at demolition site
- to use a value given for recovered fuels by Statistics Finland (0,57 kg CO2 / kg)
- When the share of combustible waste fraction cannot be assessed a default value or 10% can be used which leads to the emission value of 0,057 kg CO2 / kg of all mixed waste.

Resources.Name: Transportation of building materials (m2)
Resources.GeneralComment: The emission factors for transportation of building materials (simplified calculation method per square meter) were assessed based on statistical data and earlier research results.
Resources.TechnologyDescriptionAndIncludedProcesse: CO2-emissions from transportation of building materials in CO2e/m2 are calculated using the (LIPASTO based) average emission factors in co2data.fi that include diesel acquisition (JEC WTT 4a). Weight of the building materials per square meter and average transportation distance and load was estimated from the Finnish statistics and recent research.

Resources.Name: Transport, bulk carrier, medium
Resources.GeneralComment: The selected ship types are the types that were considered relevant for calculating the emissions of waterborne freight transport used in construction process. JEC v.4.a. report describes the well-to-tank emissions of fuels used in transport process.  JEC well-to-tank values were added to LIPASTO emission values to represent the actual values of the whole transportation process.
Resources.TechnologyDescriptionAndIncludedProcesse: Waterborne transport’s technological progress has been relatively slow, and the lifetime of vessels is long contributing to slow turnover rate of the fleet. However, in recent years engine technologies and improved use efficiencies have decreased fuel consumption and emissions.

Resources.Name: Transport, container train, diesel
Resources.GeneralComment: VTT LIPASTO offers average rail transport emission values for the year 2016. JEC v.4.a. report describes the well-to-tank emissions of fuels used in transport process. JEC well-to-tank values were added to LIPASTO emission values to represent the actual values of the entire transportation process
Resources.TechnologyDescriptionAndIncludedProcesse: Emissions from rail transport as a whole are small compared to other modes of transport. In 2017, electric traction accounted for 89,7 per cent of train kilometers, according to VR. Furthermore, trains can utilize braking energy.

Resources.Name: Transport, earth moving truck, 40% load, highway
Resources.GeneralComment:
The emission factors are based on LIPASTO unit emission system as well as JEC v4.a well-to-tank emissions. The selected vehicle types are the types that were considered relevant for calculating the emissions of freight transport used in construction. JEC v.4.a. report describes the well-to-tank emissions of fuels used in road transport. JEC well-to-tank values were added to LIPASTO emission values to represent the actual values of the whole transportation process. For cargo, 50 %-load can be used as a general value when the load cannot be utilized during return trip.

Values are provided for 50 % and 40 % loads. For example, 50 % load is in effect the same as full (100 %) load one way and return load empty (0 %) and results in the same amount of kg CO2e emissions. This means that emission factor for 50 % load can be used for both outward and return journey.
Resources.TechnologyDescriptionAndIncludedProcesse: There are six EURO emission standard classes for road transport. In addition, there’s a voluntary European EEV (enhanced environmentally friendly vehicle) standard that’s been set between EURO V and VI classification.  Based on LIPASTO, highway and urban driving consumption and emissions have significant difference in transporting goods, which is why it’s been divided into the two classes in this database. Well-to-tank JEC v4.a report describes processes of producing, transporting, manufacturing and distributing fuels and gives emission factors for different types of fuels, production routes and transport methods.

Resources.Name: Radiator, water circuit

Resources.GeneralComment: In terms of the A1-A3 emissions, the impacts of radiators are mostly based on steel and its GWP, as stainless steel is the main component of the product. As with any steel-based product, whether the steel used is from scrap materials or plain virgin materials has a significant impact on the GWP value of the product.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: The radiators market in Finland leader is Rettig Lämpö. However, there is no significant domestic manufacturing, and the predominant source of imports is Eastern Europe.

Resources.Name: Ready-mix concrete, C20/25, GWP.REF
Resources.StdDescription: Concrete - Specification, performance, production and conformity.
Resources.GeneralComment: Ready-mixed concrete is made by mixing the main raw materials cement, water and aggregate in a controlled proportion (according to recipe). The composition varies, but simplified concrete recipe contain cement around 12% and aggregates about 80%. Chemical admixtures are used to improve fresh and hardened concrete properties. Energy consumption for concrete mixing is small, raw-material transportation in Finland is also reasonable. Main environmental impacts come from the use of raw materials, process emissions of cement (decomposition of limestone) and the use of energy raw materials.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: The domestic sales of ready-mixed concrete were 2.7 million concrete cubes, and the turnover was EUR 325 million (2019). In 2020 net sales were slightly lower, totaling EUR 300.3 million euros. According to sales, the fours largest sellers of ready-mixed concrete are Rudus Oy, Ruskon Betoni Oy, Lujabetoni Oy, Swerock Oy.

Resources.Name: Crushed rock
Resources.StdDescription: Aggregates for concrete.
Resources.GeneralComment: The main thing affecting the carbon footprint is the energy source, the relative amount of diesel used compared to electricity and the electricity profile of the country where the aggregates are produced. The values published by NCC and Skanska in Sweden are considered as relevant results also from the viewpoint of Finland. However, the values have been revised considering that the GWP value for the Finnish electricity is higher than the global warming potential of electricity in Sweden.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Aggregates used in Finland are produced in Finland. Some export to Estonia. Manufacturers include Rudus, Swerock (ex. YIT), Destia, NCC and Seepsula.

Conversions.Value: Density 1500 kg/m3

Resources.Name: Sandwich panel, steel, mineral wool insulation
Resources.StdDescription: Cold formed welded structural hollow sections of non-alloy and fine grain steel
Resources.GeneralComment: Several relevant EPDs are available for steel products. Many of the EPDs are corporate/company specific values but those often represent several product types and/or several manufacturing plants even in different countries. Scrap content significantly affects the GWP value and the GWP benefits beyond the system boundaries.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: In Finland, manufactures of structural steel products and materials are for instance SSAB Europe Oy, Ruukki Construction Oy, Nordec Oy, Peikko Finland Oy, and Aulis Lundell Oy. The market is largely domestic regarding steel-based end products used in construction (structures, sandwich panels and profiled sheetings). All hot-rolled profiles for manufacturing structures are imported, but also for those the end products are manufactured in Finland (for instance by Nordec and Peikko).

Conversions.Value: Check full background report. Insulation thickness, density, panel weight, and GWP per m2 values are based on the EPD owned by Ruukki (RTS EPD).  The values calculated per kg are 1,8 – 2,2.

Conversions.Value:
Insulation thickness, density (38 kg/m3), panel weight and GWP per m2 values are based on EPD owned by Ruukki and published by RTS. GWP (A1-A3)) calculated per kg is 2,6 kg/kg for all listed alternatives. Listed alternatives are
- thickness 100 mm , weight 11 kg/m2
- thickness 120 mm, weight 11,7 kg/m2
- thickness 160 mm, weight 13 kg/m2

Resources.Name: Sawn timber
Resources.StdDescription: Timber structures. Strength graded structural timber with rectangular cross section. Part 1: General requirements
Resources.GeneralComment: The manufacturing process includes the following phases: log sorting and peeling, sawing, drying, quality sorting and packaging. In Finland, wood harvested from certified sources is used in the manufacture of dried sawn timber. The drying process and the type of fuels used in drying have an essential impact on the energy consumption of sawn timber. The average value is calculated on the basis of the results published by Sahateollisuus, Stora Enso, and Swedish Wood for sawn timber (32 kg/m3, 0,068 kg/kg) and apply the results published by Sahateollisuus for planed timber (36 kg/m3, 0,075 kg/kg).
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Several manufacturers produce sawn timber in Finland. Metsä Wood, Stora Enso, UPM, and Versowood belong to the biggest industrial manufacturers. The main part of sawn timber used in the Finnish construction is manufactured in Finland. The imports to Finland in 2018 was in total 11,6 million cubic meter of which 63% pulpwood, 27% wood chips, and 10% logs, firewood, impregnated wood, and waste wood. The total use of logs in saw industry was 27 million m3 in 2018. By assuming that roughly 0,5-1 million m3 logs is imported, it can be estimated that the share of imported raw material for saw industry is rather low.

Conversions.Value: GWP fossil (a1-A3)=32 kg/m3. Average density 474 kg/m3.

Resources.GeneralComment: The manufacturing process includes the following phases: log sorting and peeling, sawing, drying, quality sorting and packaging. In Finland, wood harvested from certified sources is used in the manufacture of dried sawn timber. The drying process and the type of fuels used in drying have an essential impact on the energy consumption of sawn timber. The average value is calculated on the basis of the results published by Sahateollisuus, Stora Enso, and Swedish Wood for sawn timber (32 kg/m3, 0,068 kg/kg) and apply the results published by Sahateollisuus for planed timber (36 kg/m3, 0,075 kg/kg).

Resources.Name: Waste processing, bricks and lime sand bricks
Resources.GeneralComment:
The after-use phase is divided to the following four sub-phases:
• C1 Deconstruction demolition
• C2 Transport
• C3 Waste processing
• C4 Disposal
GWP for demolition is given for C1, C3, and C4, C2 is dealt with on the bases of GWP for transportation service.
GWP value for C1 is given for three different building types.
GWP for waste processing is given separately for a few building materials. The data is mainly based on EPDs.
GWP for C4 is based on the emission value for recovered fuels and on the assumption of the share of combustible waste fraction.
Resources.TechnologyDescriptionAndIncludedProcesse:
The main part of mixed waste assessed by weight - consists of concrete and other mineral materials. Mixed waste from building sites is not applicable for combustion. The different fractions need to be separated on buildings sites , or at latest on waste separation plants .
Statistics Finland has published emission values for different kinds of fuels. The value for recovered fuels is 0,57 kg CO2/kg.
The proposal for phase C4 is
- to provide a generic emission value with regard to the building-scale amount of combustible waste generated at demolition site
- to use a value given for recovered fuels by Statistics Finland (0,57 kg CO2 / kg)
- When the share of combustible waste fraction cannot be assessed a default value or 10% can be used which leads to the emission value of 0,057 kg CO2 / kg of all mixed waste.

Resources.Name: Waste processing, concrete materials
Resources.GeneralComment:
The after-use phase is divided to the following four sub-phases:
• C1 Deconstruction demolition
• C2 Transport
• C3 Waste processing
• C4 Disposal
GWP for demolition is given for C1, C3, and C4, C2 is dealt with on the bases of GWP for transportation service.
GWP value for C1 is given for three different building types.
GWP for waste processing is given separately for a few building materials. The data is mainly based on EPDs.
GWP for C4 is based on the emission value for recovered fuels and on the assumption of the share of combustible waste fraction.
Resources.TechnologyDescriptionAndIncludedProcesse:
The main part of mixed waste assessed by weight - consists of concrete and other mineral materials. Mixed waste from building sites is not applicable for combustion. The different fractions need to be separated on buildings sites , or at latest on waste separation plants .
Statistics Finland has published emission values for different kinds of fuels. The value for recovered fuels is 0,57 kg CO2/kg.
The proposal for phase C4 is
- to provide a generic emission value with regard to the building-scale amount of combustible waste generated at demolition site
- to use a value given for recovered fuels by Statistics Finland (0,57 kg CO2 / kg)
- When the share of combustible waste fraction cannot be assessed a default value or 10% can be used which leads to the emission value of 0,057 kg CO2 / kg of all mixed waste.

Resources.Name: Waste processing, glass
Resources.GeneralComment:
The after-use phase is divided to the following four sub-phases:
• C1 Deconstruction demolition
• C2 Transport
• C3 Waste processing
• C4 Disposal
GWP for demolition is given for C1, C3, and C4, C2 is dealt with on the bases of GWP for transportation service.
GWP value for C1 is given for three different building types.
GWP for waste processing is given separately for a few building materials. The data is mainly based on EPDs.
GWP for C4 is based on the emission value for recovered fuels and on the assumption of the share of combustible waste fraction.

Resources.Name: Drinking water pipe, PEX
Resources.StdDescription: Plastics piping systems for hot and cold water installations
Resources.GeneralComment: In terms of the PEX pipe, the biggest emission impacts come from the raw materials. The manufacturing energy use does have an impact on the GWP of the product, although it is generally a smaller one when compared to PEX related raw material emissions.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: The domestic manufacturing market share is unknown. Imports are predominantly coming from Europe. The Finnish market for plastic pipe manufacturing is dominated by Uponor Finland and Pipelife Finland. In terms of the overall market volume, plastic pipes are estimated to be the leading solution on the market. In addition of plastic pipes, drinking water pipes in the market are also made from composite materials as well as copper. In terms of import, composite is mainly imported from Germany, whereas cross-linked polyethylene (PEX) pipes are mainly imported from Sweden.

Conversions.Value: PRODUCT’S DIMENSION 1m of pipe with a diameter of 15 mm

Resources.Name: Water pump
Resources.StdDescription: Minimum required efficiency of rotodynamic water pumps
Resources.GeneralComment: The main constituents by mass of the water pump are cast iron, plastics and steel. Together with the manufacturing energy use, these constituents contribute the most to the product’s GWP. If considering also the use phase of the product, this could have significant impact to the product’s carbon emissions.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: The domestic market for water pumps is led by Grundfos, Wilo and Xylem. However, the domestic manufacturing market share is not known. The import of water pumps comes predominantly from Europe.

Conversions.Value: Product dimensions 99 cm x 209 cm 17 cm.

Resources.Name: Water vapour barrier, PE
Resources.GeneralComment: Plastic water vapour barriers are plastic foils typically made of polyethylene. The thickness of the foil is typically roughly 0.2 mm. The dominating issue from the viewpoint of carbon footprint is the manufacture of polyethylene raw material. The proposal is to apply the same value as published by EPD Norge by Rani Plast. The value is in reasonable balance with the carbon footprint values published by some other manufacturers and the ecoprofiles published by Plastics Europe. The production of the polymer raw material has a dominating effect on the GWP result.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: There is production of polymer in several plants in Europe. There is manufacturing of products in Finland, for example Rani Plast Oy and Isover. No information of markets. However, as the raw material dominates, the variation between PE-based products is not big.

Conversions.Value:
0.40 kg/m2 (0.2 kg/m2, thickness 0.2 mm); 
0.46 kg/m2 considering overlapping (1.15*0.2 kg/m2)

Resources.Name: Window, wood-aluminium, triple-glazed
Resources.StdDescription: Windows and external doorsets
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: The Finnish market for windows is led by domestic manufacturers, including Inwido Group companies (Pihla, Tiivi and Eskopuu) and Skaala, Kaskipuu, Fenestra, Tikli and Lammin Ikkunat. The market share of domestic manufacturing is estimated to be approximately 90%. All window glass used in Finland is imported. Share of the aluminium frames is imported as well.

Conversions.Value: PRODUCT’S DIMENSION (WxHxD) 99 cm x 99 cm x 17 cm

Resources.Name: XPS-insulation
Resources.StdDescription: Thermal insulation products for  buildings. Factory made extruded  polystyrene foam (XPS) products.  Specification.
Resources.GeneralComment: XPS foams are mostly made of polystyrene (90 to 95% by weight) and blowing agents (such as carbon dioxide) and minor amounts of additives. The production of the raw material has the main influence on the climate impact. The proposal is to apply the GWP value published by Finnfoam as it is the market leader in Finland for XPS insulation. The value is close to the average value reported by EXIBA - European Extruded Polystyrene Insulation Board Association.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: Plastic-based insulation products used in construction in Finland are mainly also manufactured Finland. Imports are relatively low because of the transportation cost of low-density products. Finnfoam (Salo) is the market leader in XPS insulation products. In addition, there are two other manufacturers, which have significantly smaller market shares.

Resources.Name: Asphalt concrete (SMA)
Resources.StdDescription: Asphalt concrete
Resources.GeneralComment: The differences in the carbon footprint come mainly from the amount of recycled material and the heating process. In case of proposed values, only virgin sources are used for manufacturing. Therefore, it is assumed that 100 % of the product will be disposed at the end-of-life phase. Carbon footprint of heating is affected by the temperature and the fuel used in heating process. In this proposal the carbon footprint has been calculated on the basis of the amount of material used in the asphalt (excluding the use of recycled asphalt). The product compositions used are based in part on PANK study material C10.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: In 2019 the production was 5.34 milj. tonnes, which was divided by the customers: Centres for Economic Development, Transport and the Environment 34 %, aviation 1 %, municipalities 22 %, private 43 %.

Conversions.Value: Density 2476 kg/m3.

Resources.Name: Ready-mix concrete, C35/45, GWP.REF
Resources.StdDescription: Concrete - Specification, performance, production and conformity.
Resources.GeneralComment: Ready-mixed concrete is made by mixing the main raw materials cement, water and aggregate in a controlled proportion (according to recipe). The composition varies, but simplified concrete recipe contain cement around 12% and aggregates about 80%. Chemical admixtures are used to improve fresh and hardened concrete properties. Energy consumption for concrete mixing is small, raw-material transportation in Finland is also reasonable. Main environmental impacts come from the use of raw materials, process emissions of cement (decomposition of limestone) and the use of energy raw materials.
Resources.GeographicalRepresentativenessDescriptio: Representative data for products purchased by the construction sector in Finland
Resources.AnnualSupplyOrProductionVolume: The domestic sales of ready-mixed concrete were 2.7 million concrete cubes, and the turnover was EUR 325 million (2019). In 2020 net sales were slightly lower, totaling EUR 300.3 million euros. According to sales, the fours largest sellers of ready-mixed concrete are Rudus Oy, Ruskon Betoni Oy, Lujabetoni Oy, Swerock Oy.

In 2020 net sales were slightly lower, totaling EUR 300.3 million euros. According to sales, the fours largest sellers of ready-mixed concrete are Rudus Oy, Ruskon Betoni Oy, Lujabetoni Oy, Swerock Oy.

Resources.Name: Ready-mix concrete, C30/37, GWP.70
Resources.StdDescription: Concrete - Specification, performance, production and conformity.
Resources.GeneralComment: Ready-mixed concrete is made by mixing the main raw materials cement, water and aggregate in a controlled proportion (according to recipe). The composition varies, but simplified concrete recipe contain cement around 12% and aggregates about 80%. Chemical admixtures are used to improve fresh and hardened concrete properties. Energy consumption for concrete mixing is small, raw-material transportation in Finland is also reasonable. Main environmental impacts come from the use of raw materials, process emissions of cement (decomposition of limestone) and the use of energy raw materials.

Resources.Name: Small residential building
Resources.GeneralComment:
The proposed emission value for building services equipment is based on data modeling of building designs from the lists of equipment and electrical components of the contractors. All sites were real construction projects. The values are given separately for the following building types: small residential building, apartment building, office, educational building/kindergarten, accommodation building/hotel, hospital, sports hall, other retail building. The unit is kg CO2e / m2. These values include whole evaluation period including maintenance and product replacements. With regard to the calculation of emissions from building technology materials, a conservative factor of 1.2 has been taken into account.

The emissions of the cooling system for educational buildings/kindergartens and small residential buildings must be added separately if the cooling system is planned. Sprinkler system for fire extinguishing is not included.
